lines.text: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Ill bring you thither, my lord, if youll vouchsafe me.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company for, from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupids bowstring and the little hangman dare not shoot at him he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his tongue speaks.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: So say Imethinks you are sadder.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I hope he be in love.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Hang him, truant! theres no true drop of blood in him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad, he wants money.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I have the toothache.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Draw it.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Hang it!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What! sigh for the toothache

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Where is but a humour or a worm.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has it.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Yet say I, he is in love.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises as, to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as, a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs: a brushes his hat o mornings what should that bode

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Hath any man seen him at the barbers

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: No, but the barbers man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennisballs.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Nay, a rubs himself with civet: can you smell him out by that

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Thats as much as to say, the sweet youths in love.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And when was he wont to wash his face

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Yea, or to paint himself for the which, I hear what they say of him.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Nay, but his jesting spirit which is now crept into a lutestring and now governed by stops.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude, conclude he is in love.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Nay, but I know who loves him.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Yes, and his ill conditions and, in despite of all, dies for him.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight or nine wise words to speak to you, which these hobbyhorses must not hear.
Exeunt BENEDICK and LEONATO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their parts with Beatrice and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet.
Enter DON JOHN

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: My lord and brother, God save you!

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Good den, brother.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: In private

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear for what I would speak of concerns him.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Whats the matter

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: [To CLAUDIO]  Means your lordship to be married tomorrow

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: You know he does.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: You may think I love you not: let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriagesurely suit ill spent and labour ill bestowed.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Why, whats the matter

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: I came hither to tell you and, circumstances shortened, for she has been too long a talking of, the lady is disloyal.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Who, Hero

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Even she Leonatos Hero, your Hero, every mans Hero:

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Disloyal

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness I could say she were worse: think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till further warrant: go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamberwindow entered, even the night before her weddingday: if you love her then, tomorrow wed her but it would better fit your honour to change your mind.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: May this be so

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I will not think it.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know: if you will follow me, I will show you enough and when you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If I see any thing tonight why I should not marry her tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show itself.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: O day untowardly turned!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: O mischief strangely thwarting!

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when you have seen the sequel.
Exeunt
